{"id":"/subscriptions/6bded6d5-a6af-43e1-96d3-bf71f6f5f8ba/resourcegroups/sm1dxne74h/providers/Microsoft.Storage/storageAccounts/teststorageforselfhelp/providers/Microsoft.Help/simplifiedSolutions/hbk16wuga5","name":"hbk16wuga5","type":"Microsoft.Help/simplifiedSolutions","properties":{"title":"Catch-all: Microsoft Graph API issues","content":"

Troubleshoot issues with the Microsoft Graph API

Notice: Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is being renamed to Microsoft Entra ID. No customer action is required. Capabilities, licensing, pricing, service level agreements, APIs, authentication and developer experiences are not impacted. Learn more.

Use the following guidance to troubleshoot Microsoft Graph API issues, including issues related to authentication, authorization, and API. You'll also find information about the end of support for Azure AD Authentication Library (ADAL) and Azure AD Graph API.

Scan the following headings and select one or more that will help resolve your issue.


End of support for Azure AD Graph API and Azure Active Directory Authentication Library

Azure Active Directory Graph API deprecation

Azure AD Graph APIs will be retired by March 30, 2024. See Important: Azure AD Graph Retirement and Powershell Module Deprecation. We want to make sure that all customers migrate off and discourage applications from taking production dependencies on Azure AD Graph. Investments in the new features and functionalities will be made only to Microsoft Graph. Going forward, we'll continue to support Azure AD Graph with security-related fixes.

We recommend prioritizing migration from Azure AD Graph to Microsoft Graph. For more information, see Migrate Azure AD Graph apps to Microsoft Graph - Microsoft Graph | Microsoft Docs.

Microsoft Entra ID and MSOnline PowerShell deprecation

Microsoft Entra ID, Microsoft Entra ID Preview, and MSOnline PowerShell cmdlets will be retired by March 30, 2024 See Important: Azure AD Graph Retirement and Powershell Module Deprecation. The three modules will continue to work with minimal investment, apart from security updates.

We encourage you to continue migrating to The Microsoft Graph PowerShell SDK because that continues to be where all our current and future PowerShell investments are being made. We're also working on tools and documentation for migrating existing scripts and PowerShell processes that rely on the Azure AD Graph and MSOnline module to the Microsoft Graph PowerShell SDK.

For more information, see Find Microsoft Entra ID and MSOnline cmdlets in Microsoft Graph PowerShell | Microsoft Docs and Migrate from Azure AD PowerShell to the Microsoft Graph PowerShell SDK | Microsoft Docs.

Azure Active Directory Authentication Library retirement

Azure Active Directory Authentication Library (ADAL) end-of-support is on June 30, 2023. While existing ADAL apps may continue to work, no support or security fixes will be provided past end-of-life. In addition, there are no planned ADAL releases prior to end-of-life for features, or planned support for new platform versions.

We recommend prioritizing the migration of your applications to Microsoft Authentication Library (MSAL). For more information about ADAL to MSAL migration, see Migrate to the Microsoft Authentication Library - Microsoft Entra | Microsoft Docs.

For more information, see September 2022 change announcements.

Videos: Migrating from Azure AD Graph to Microsoft Graph

The following videos explain more about migrating from Azure AD Graph to Microsoft Graph.





Troubleshoot Microsoft Graph API issues

Use the following troubleshooting guidance to resolve Microsoft Graph API issues.

Azure AD Graph migration

For applications using Azure AD Graph, see migrate Azure AD Graph apps to Microsoft Graph.

  1. Start with the app migration planning checklist.
  2. Your Azure app registration portal shows which applications use Azure AD Graph.
  3. Review your apps source code, and if applicable, contact independent software vendors (ISVs) or app providers. Microsoft support can provide a list of Azure AD Graph usage in your tenant.
  4. If you're having issues, post a question on Microsoft Q&A and tag it with azure-ad-graph-deprecation, or post your question on StackOverflow with the azureadgraph-deprecation tag.

Review the following resources for more information:

  • Azure AD Graph to Microsoft Graph migration frequently asked questions
  • Configure how users consent to applications
  • How to recognize differences between delegated and application permissions

Upgrade from Microsoft Entra ID and MSOnline PowerShell to Microsoft Graph PowerShell

Microsoft Entra ID, Microsoft Entra ID Preview, and MSOnline PowerShell modules are planned for deprecation. Microsoft Graph PowerShell is the PowerShell module to use for interacting with Microsoft Entra ID and other Microsoft services.

  • Why upgrade to Microsoft Graph PowerShell?
  • Steps to follow when upgrading to MS Graph PowerShell
  • Limitations

Cmdlet mappings from Microsoft Entra ID and MSOnline PowerShell modules to MS Graph PowerShell module

  • Microsoft Entra ID to Microsoft Graph PowerShell by category
  • MSOnline to Microsoft Graph PowerShell

Authentication or authorization issues

See the following resources to resolve authentication or authorization issues:

  • Authorization errors can occur for several reasons, most of which generate a 403 error, with a few exceptions. For example, the following scenarios can lead to authorization errors:

    • Incorrect access token acquisition flows
    • Poorly configured permission scopes
    • Lack of consent
    • Lack of permissions
      For more information, see Resolve Microsoft Graph authorization errors.

  • Learn how to implement the OAuth 2.0 authorization code grant flow. See Get access on behalf of a user.

  • Learn how to program directly against the code grant (PKCE) flow in your application using any language, see Microsoft identity platform and OAuth 2.0 authorization code flow.

  • Configure a service and use the OAuth client credentials grant flow to get an access token. See Get access without a user.

  • Program directly against the client credentials flow in your application. See Microsoft identity platform and the OAuth 2.0 client credentials flow.

  • Program directly against the resource owner password credential (ROPC) flow in your application. See Microsoft identity platform and OAuth 2.0 resource owner password credentials.

  • The Microsoft identity platform only supports ROPC for Microsoft Entra tenants, not personal accounts. This means that you must use a tenant-specific endpoint, for example, "//login.microsoftonline.com/{TenantId_or_Name}" or the organization's endpoint.

  • Personal accounts that are invited to a Microsoft Entra tenant can't use ROPC.

  • Accounts that don't have passwords can't sign in through ROPC. In this case, we recommend using a different flow for your app.

  • If users need to use multifactor authentication (MFA) to sign in to the application, they'll be blocked instead.

  • ROPC is not supported in hybrid identity federation scenarios. For example, Microsoft Entra ID and Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) previously authenticated on-premises accounts. If users are full-page redirected to an on-premises identity provider, Microsoft Entra ID is not able to test the username and password against that identity provider. Pass-through authentication is supported with ROPC, however.

  • An exception to a hybrid identity federation scenario would be the following: home realm discovery (HRD) policy with AllowCloudPasswordValidation set to TRUE will enable ROPC flow to work for federated users when the on-premises password is synced to the cloud. For more information, see Enable direct ROPC authentication of federated users for legacy applications.

Query data from API

  • Microsoft Graph supports optional query parameters you can use to specify and control the amount of data returned in a response. The support for the exact query parameters varies from one API operation to another, and depending on the API, can differ between the v1.0 and beta endpoints. See Use query parameters to customize responses for more information.
    • user resource type. This represents a Microsoft Entra user account and inherits from directoryObject. For performance reasons, the create, get, and list operations return only a subset of more commonly used properties by default. These default properties are noted in the properties section. To get any of the properties that are not returned by default, specify them in a $select OData query option.
    • attachment resource type. You can add related content to a user event, message, or post in the form of an attachment. Attachment is the base resource for the following derived types of attachments:
      • A file (fileAttachment resource).
      • An item (contact, event or message, represented by an itemAttachment resource).
      • A link to a file (referenceAttachment resource).
      • schemaExtension resource type (schema extensions). Schema extensions allow you to define a schema to extend and add strongly typed custom data to a resource type. The custom data appears as a complex type on the extended resource. See the schema extension example to learn how to add custom data to groups.

Microsoft Graph API endpoints

See the following resources for more information:

  • Office 365 URLs and IP address ranges - This article contains most of the endpoints for Azure and M365, including Azure and Microsoft Graph.
  • Microsoft Graph REST API v1.0 reference.
  • Microsoft Graph beta endpoint reference.

Reports and logs

  • Microsoft Entra ID tracks user activity and creates reports that help you understand how your users access and use Microsoft Entra services. Use the Microsoft Graph API for Microsoft Entra ID to analyze the data in these reports and to create custom solutions tailored to your organization's specific needs. The availability of these activity reports is governed by the Microsoft Entra data retention policies.

For more information, see:

  • Activity reports API overview.
  • Data retention policies.
  • With Microsoft Graph, you can access Microsoft 365 usage reports resources to get information about how people in your business are using Microsoft 365 services. For example, you can identify who's using a service a lot and reaching quotas, or who may not need a Microsoft 365 license at all, see Working with Microsoft 365 usage reports in Microsoft Graph.

Expose a web API

  • QuickStart: Configure an application to expose a web API. In this QuickStart, register a web API with the Microsoft identity platform and expose it to client apps by adding an example scope. By registering your web API and exposing it through scopes, you can provide permission-based access to its resources to authorized users and client apps that access your API.


Common issues and solutions

The API I'm calling doesn't work

  • Test Microsoft Graph APIs in your tenant or a demo tenant. Also, check out the sample queries in Microsoft Graph Explorer.
  • Learn how to configure the code for your daemon application that calls web APIs, see Daemon app that calls web APIs - code configuration.

Where can I check the status of service availability and connectivity?

  • The service availability and connectivity of the underlying services that can be accessed through Microsoft Graph can impact on the overall availability and performance of Microsoft Graph.
    • For Microsoft Entra service health, check the status of Security + Identity services listed in the Azure status page.
    • For Office services that contribute to Microsoft Graph, check the status of services listed in the Office Service Health Dashboard. Microsoft Graph authorization errors can be a result of several issues, most of which generate a 401 or 403 error.

Where can I find more information on errors and known issues?

  • Microsoft Graph error response information
  • Known issues with Microsoft Graph

Relevant results from the web

Azure Docs
Consolidated Billing

...billing, enabling developers to receive a unified invoice from Azure for all their API plans, rather than managing separate bills from various operators. This streamlined approach not only reduces ...


Community
azure billing

I was cancelled my subscription but still it is billing.



","provisioningState":"Succeeded","appendix":{}}}
